title: Which parties, from among the Green Party, the FDP, and the Left, will be part of Germany's next governing coalition?
possible_answers: The Left Party and the Green Party, but not the FDP
The Left Party and the FDP, but not the Green Party
The Green Party and the FDP, but not the Left Party
The Left Party, the Green Party, and the FDP

BUT what about the ITALIAN elections?!

Germany's Social Democrats agree to join 'grand coalition' with Merkel
http://www.france24.com/en/20180304-germanys-socialist-democrats-agree-join-grand-coalition-with-merkel

Angela Merkel set for 4th term after Social Democrats OK coalition Jordans (2018) March 4, states that: BERLIN (AP) — Germany ended months of political uncertainty Sunday when Chancellor Angela Merkel gained the support needed to preserve her governing coalition and secure a fourth term as leader of Europe’s most powerful economy. The center-left Social Democrats voted overwhelmingly to remain in a coalition with Merkel’s conservative bloc, after difficult and drawn-out negotiations triggered by September’s elections, which saw the rise of a new right-wing force in German politics and raised questions about Merkel’s future. Parliament is expected to meet March 14 to re-elect Merkel as chancellor, ending the longest time Germany has been without a new government after elections in its postwar history (para. 1-3). Jordans, F. (2018). Angela Merkel set for 4th term after Social Democrats OK coalition. Associated Press. Retrieved from 
https://apnews.com/44faa80d67554ca4b4517f8bd0a23721
The Green Party and FDP have too many conflicts and contradictory demands to exist in the same coalition.

Dateline 3-4-2018 A political impasse that kept Germany in limbo for more than five months ended Sunday as the center-left Social Democrats voted to join a government led by Chancellor Angela Merkel’s conservatives. -- https://www.washingtonpost.com/world/germany-will-finally-have-a-government-after-social-democrats-clear-the-way-for-merkels-fourth-term/2018/03/04/837b6486-1bcf-11e8-98f5-ceecfa8741b6_story.html
The FDP and Greens can't stand each other for too long

In America, the Green Party is weak and disorganized, so any coalition would seek to add it, it being easier to control or bully, so it is favored slightly. The left will be stronger in backlash to the recent surge of right wing love, so that is favored as well. 
It seems vastly less likely that 3 organizations will be able to unify and most likely at all that none do.

Merkel's Successors Are Waiting for Her to Step Down or Stumble Donahue (2018) February 28, states that: Angela Merkel watched from the sidelines on an icy afternoon in Berlin this week as the woman tipped by many to replace her brought more than 1,000 Christian Democratic Union delegates to their feet. “We can only be strong if we engage all those people in the political center,” Annegret Kramp-Karrenbauer, the 55-year-old state premier handpicked by the German chancellor to be CDU general secretary, told a rapturous party convention on Monday. Delegates eager for fresh faces at the top rewarded her with 99 percent support (para. 1-2). As allies and adversaries adjust to a Germany in transition, Merkel is up for re-election as party chairwoman at the CDU’s next convention in December. That would position her to lead the party until 2020, the year before the next scheduled election. Should she decide against seeking a fifth term, that would probably be the moment to hand over the reins (para. 13). Donahue, P. (2018). Merkel's Successors Are Waiting for Her to Step Down or Stumble. Bloomberg. Politics. Retrieved from
https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2018-03-01/merkel-successors-circle-waiting-for-her-to-step-down-or-stumble

Germany's Merkel wins party nod to renew coalition with Social Democrats https://www.reuters.com/article/us-germany-politics/germanys-merkel-wins-party-nod-to-renew-coalition-with-social-democrats-idUSKCN1GA01L The more formidable hurdle to ending a five-month political impasse comes next week, however. On March 4, results of a binding postal vote by members of the center-left SPD will be announced and they are far less certain. “Now I can only say to the SPD that I hope many members feel the same responsibility for giving Germany a good government,” Merkel said in an interview with broadcaster RTL. “I think we can achieve a lot together for Germany and its people.” The vote at a CDU congress followed Merkel’s announcement of her picks for a new, younger cabinet intended to revive the party, which has been riven by disagreements over how to respond to the Alternative for Germany (AfD) since losing votes to the far-right party in national elections in September. The CDU’s youth wing has called for the party to renew itself in the wake of its worst election result since 1949 in September and Merkel, 63, stressed in her speech to delegates at the CDU gathering that younger faces were in the new team.
The coalition is likely to be with the SPD

The main possibilities now are GroKo, new elections or CDU/CSU minority government, which all fall under 'none of the above'. There is a small chance that the CDU/CSU will make further overtures to FDP and the greens. I imagine there is roughly zero chance of Merkel wanting to work with die Linke, or vice versa.

Die Linke (The Left Party) is the descendant of the former East German communist party and other extreme leftist groups from the former West Germany. Participating as a coalition partner with the center-right CDU or moderate FDP  would be a very strange marriage. Although the Greens are also a liberal party, they are somewhat more moderate than the "Reds," so despite their disagreements with the FDP outlined in several of the articles, they are more likely willing to compromise. Of course there is a possibility that no coalition will be formed at all.
The FDP is extremely likely to form a government coalition.  The Green portrays itself as an opposition party and the Left is an extreme opposition parity.
I think it is likely that the SDU and CDU will figure out how to rule or they will have new elections.

Looking like it will be a grand coalition - SPD and CDU but with lots of grumbling about AfD being the potential opposition. Still not a fait accompli and if there's a major crack it could be back to the polls - which would likely see AfD poll stronger which none of the other parties want! Still very interesting times and stuck between a rock and a hard place comes to mind.

Talks have failed between the CDU/CSU and the FDP and Greens and there appears to be and agreement to form a grand coalition between the CDU/CSU and the SPD which represent the largest block of both party and constituency votes in the current Bundestag . The  Green party tends to be more radical so my next ranking was for the Left and the FDP with a small percentage for all three.

The deal is now all-but-finalized; the remaining 1% is Murphy's.

Expected to conclude coalition talks this week. Only CSU/CDU partner in talks at moment is SPD. It looks like if those talks fail the most likely outcome is new elections, perhaps a resurrected attempt at the CSU/CDU Jamaica alliance with the Greens & FDP.

Current negotiations have a good chance of success and involve none of the identified opposition parties. However, success is uncertain. In the event of a breakdown, two parties are needed. The FDP is the closest match politically; the Greens the most likely to resist an alliance.

Things don't look good for a coalition of any kind at this point. It appears that the historic partnership with the SDP is threatened due to the drubbing SDP took at the polls, they seem to be looking for another option outside of ongoing partnership with Merkel. The FDP's pro-business agenda is at odds with the Green Party and the Left, but it's more conceivable that the Green and FDP would swallow their differences and join rather than including the Left party. A partnership with the Left and Green Party would lean too far left for Merkel and her constituents. The most likely result is that there will not be any agreement and a coalition government will not be formed. In my view, the next most likely result is that the SDP will reconcile their differences and seek to extract concessions in exchange for their ongoing support, but this is much less likely.
There are too less commonalities between those parties and the larger ones, which would lead a coalition.

The left party won't be accepted by CDU/CSU as a coalition partner, so all these options are a no go. FDP has declared publicly not to be part of the coalition after having negotiated with CDU/CSU, so they won't come back to discussions after that. There's a very small chance of Green Party and FDP in case the discussions with the social democrats SPD won't work out. But the SPD party members voted for a coalition, this seems by far the most likely option, even though SPD lost a lot of votes due to their participation in the coalition in the past.

FDP has announced that it rejected the coalition with CDU because of Merkel. Since Merkel wants to stay there will be no Jamaika coalition, means with small parties. What remains is the SPD, which is the main opposition party, and which is not happy to be again with Merkel in government as a little brother. The chances for the need of reelection are there for high.

Noted here are talks in the new year. No coalition before 2018 and maybe snap election instead. https://uk.reuters.com/article/uk-germany-politics/german-conservatives-eye-65000-cap-on-migrants-idUKKBN1EH04Q
When talks resume in January, Merkel will likely align with SDP, to avoid a re-election. Unlikely the Greens will be included.

Depending on the description 'none of the above' is the only probable possibility as a coalition talks between Greens, FDP and CDU/CSU have failed. As neither the SPD nor a minority government formed by CDU/CSU and the Greens are listed there is no option that accounts for the current situation.
Very interesting!  Either the SPD comes to the party or there is another election so the other options aren't a real possibility.

Merkel presses cautious SPD over joining new German coalition Escritt (2017) November 27, states that: BERLIN (Reuters) - Chancellor Angela Merkel piled pressure on Monday on the Social Democrats (SPD) to rejoin a “grand coalition” with her conservatives, arguing that the European Union and the wider world urgently needed a stable German government in place. More than two months after its Sept. 24 national election, Europe’s economic and political powerhouse is still without a government and officials say coalition talks may now properly begin only in the new year. “There are European elections in 2019... so there is a big expectation that we take positions,” she told reporters, referring to proposals by European Commission President Jean-Claude Juncker and by French President Emmanuel Macron on the future governance of the EU’s currency and economic union. Merkel also cited conflicts in the Middle East, tensions with Russia and relations with the United States as factors that required a Germany “capable of acting”. David McAllister, an executive committee member of Merkel’s Christian Democrats (CDU), echoed her views in comments to Reuters, adding that Germany needed to iron out its stance on key EU issues ahead of European Parliament elections in 2019 (para. 1-5). Escritt, T. (2017). Merkel presses cautious SPD over joining new German coalition. Reuters. World News. Retrieved from
https://www.reuters.com/article/us-germany-politics/merkel-presses-cautious-spd-over-joining-new-german-coalition-idUSKBN1DR0YJ Europe global environment mean Germany needs stable government, Merkel says Escritt, T. (2017). Europe, global environment mean Germany needs stable government, Merkel says. Reuters. World News. Retrieved from
https://www.reuters.com/article/us-germany-politics-merkel/europe-global-environment-mean-germany-needs-stable-government-merkel-says-idUSKBN1DR1HK

To establish a top-level split between the idea of a minority coallition and otherwise, I'm looking at the votes and the negotiations thus far. It seems that leadership of the two leaders (CDU/CSU + SDP) oppose minority coallition now as a grand coallition appears possible following failed negotiations for a Jamaica coallition. I'm adding to that the fact that the AfD would like to thwart practically any coallition. That weights 69% against any such minority coallition. The FDP platform would be sensible for a coallition, but they have walked away from the table and ended the talks. Based on their approach to negotiation, I'm downgrading their likely appearnace in a coallition. I partitioned the probabilities of minority coallitions first against the inclusion of FDP. That path may even require rescue of a new negotiator if it were to by sought again.

Once again the very unusual situation requires hair-splitting, nitpicking parsing of the Q.  The "next governing coalition" probably won't emerge until after this Q expires, so:  Wil the GJedi extend the deadline until there is a "next governing coalition"?  Will they interpret the Q to ask who will be in a coalition before 29 December?  Do they mean none of the above parties or none of the above combinations?  And what about Naomi? It is frustrating to spend more time trying to figure out what the question means than what the answer might be.  One hopes, but does not expect, that the GJedi will clarify this.  Meantime, going with the guess that they mean to shut this down on the initially announced date.

It's not 100% certain that new elections are going to be held.  The situation looks bleak we should remember that German governing-party negotiations take some time and the break-down of negotiations, while severe, might not be a catastrophe--it could just be different.  The President has called for the parties to come back and negotiate.  Or, Mrs. Merkl could step aside.  There is still enough uncertainty that we shouldn't say 100% no compromise.  The most likely coalition is still the Jamaica coalition.

The reasons I named before for Jamaika and against the other options are still there, but the coalition conversations for Jamaika have been ended by the FDP. I am unsure if this has to mean a definite end to this possibility,

The failure of "Jamaika" in Germany, the project of a black-yellow-green coalition, is at first a failure of Angela Merkel. Two were his rebellious partners, who failed to do so: the Bavarian Social Democrats, the Liberals and her "friends" Csu. Both were stubborn about the issue of stopping the reunion of family members of refugees from war zones, a ridiculous question for two reasons. One, because the two-year break in 2016 ends in March 2018, and in any case, two, under strong suspicion of unconstitutionality, since Grundgesetz specifically protects the family. SIDE NOTE: A party called "Christian" wants to prevent the arrival of family members from areas under the bombs and / or Assad is not just sad, but painful - since it is numerically small, a few dozen of thousands of people, women and children, who would surely make the males more peaceful and integrable. Two issues emerged: Merkel lost her grip on leadership, and negatively highlighted the political stature of liberal leader Lindner, the main author of the breakup. However, not all damage comes to harm. Europe should rejoice. The idea of Fdp (Liberals) was the clear return to the anti-Draghi times. With the Liberals to the Government, Germany would become a major unifying brake towards the sharing of risks and benefits.  The Euro may come down now, for the benefit of EU exports. The most difficult task lies with Merkel: to acknowledge her failure and to withdraw. Or, if still possible, her resurgence from the ashes of the disastrous election result for her and the Cdu / Csu and show that she really had a broad-minded political project. As consolation prize for Germany, the economy is growing as it has never been for years, the sixth in a row, full of employment and personal scarcity everywhere: now Germany also makes the Spanish and Italian experiences that weak governments are doing well to the economy and if Germany comes out slightly lowered, smaller, it is not a bad thing. It has become a European country like any other.
Presumably "NOTA" means none of the above combos, not none of the above parties.  This will probably clear up over the next couple of days.  Or not.

Reversing my forecast on news of the FDP walking out of coalition talks. If they stay away, the only realistic way forward is either a minority government of CDU with the Greens, or a new election, both of which are "none of the above".

They may be betting things will turn out better with a new election. Reuters today said they were far apart. I am going to move up percent on no coalition with snap election.

There is a talk of the "Jamaica Coalition" which has been accomplished twice before so I think the basic odds of that occurring are favorable, at least a 2 out of 3 because I don't think any of the parties in negotiations want to risk a reelection (like Britain). These negotiations could take awhile maybe till Christmas or later so my money right now is on compromise. https://www.thelocal.de/20171107/green-party-signals-big-concessions-on-diesel-and-coal-in-coalition-talks https://www.economist.com/blogs/kaffeeklatsch/2017/10/road-jamaica-0

The Green Party and FDP are making necessary compromises in anticipation of Merkel's November 16 deadline, so the momentum is building for the Jamaica coalition.  Whether they will be able to effectively govern even over the medium term is by no means clear.

Very difficult to see why the Left Party would join, they have more to gain as an opposition party to the CDU/CSU.  The FDP and Green could work, although government would be weak vs. A CDU CSU collation. A Jamaica coalition looks very likely. Can’t see the AfD getting into government given Germany’s history.  The only I other I could think of would be the SPD deciding to change its decision, and say that its willing to join with CDU/CSU. In this case they’d still need to work with another party, likely the Greens, But the government would arguably be stronger.

The debate is not about who will be part of the next government, but how to build a consens around a common political objective. Considering the loud bickering about many essential issues occuring right now, the "null hypothesis" (no government at all) remains a distinct possibility.

Betting on Jamaica coalition working out. "Despite falling support, a clear majority — 68 percent — said the three-way coalition is likely to emerge to govern Germany once negotiations conclude. If talks fail, 75 percent said they wanted a new election while 20 percent preferred a minority government. 
Politico.eu
The left party can't even agree to join in a coalition with the two other left wing parties, the chances of it forming a coalition with the Christian Democrats is zero.

"Merkel, seeking a fourth term as chancellor, hopes to reach agreement in the exploratory talks by Nov. 16."

A few comments: 
Based on policy, the left party and the FDP cannot be in the government together, because their policies directly contradict. Additionally, CDU and Left Party are highly unlikely ever to form a coalition. Mathematically, the SPD cannot form a government, because SPD + LINKE + GRUENE < 355 necessary for majority.  Option 1: 
The left and Green Party, without the FDP, is most likely in a leftist coalition of SPD + Green + LEFT. However, this does not form a majority. It would require the AFD to join. However, this would not create a working government. 
As a result, I view the likelihood of this occurring at 1%.  Option 2: 
The economic policies of the LEFT and FDP are pretty much directly contradictory, as the LEFT contains the SED, which governed East Germany, and the FDP is the most pro-business party in the German Bundestag. As a result, I view the likelihood of this occurring at 1% as well.  Option 3: 
The Green Party and the FDP would govern in a coalition with the CDU/CSU. This is known as the Jamaica coalition. The coalition would have significant tensions, but it is possible, because it is in the interests of all the parties to compromise, because no one knows what a new election would bring. Additionally, this is the opportunity for the Greens and the FDP to implement their policies. I think the negotiations may be protracted, but that this is the most likely option. Consequently, I rate this at 60%.  Option 4: 
I don't think that having the LEFT and the FDP in a coalition would be stable. The only possibility of this occurring would be in a national crisis, in which a grand coalition of major parties is necessary. This could conceivably occur in a war with Russia, but I view this as unlikely. Otherwise, such a coalition is unlikely, because of ideological challenges, and because the Jamaica coalition would give the majority necessary. I rate this possibility 1%.  Option 5: 
Option 5 wins if no government is formed and new elections are held. This would be possible if the current Jamaica coalition talks collapse. This would require all parties believing that they have a stronger position after a new election. However, as no one knows what would happen, this is highly risky. As a result, I view this as a distinct possibility, but less likely than a Jamaica coalition. I give this the possibility of the remaining 37%.
Wisdom of the crowds bandwagoning here, got no interest or history of Merkel and German politics.  What are the numbers they have and what is the threshold of majority in the Bund?

The CDU and the Left are both extremely unlikely to want to govern together. From what every party has been saying, it looks  like the Green, the FDP and the CDU will govern (tagesschau.de). The CDU would prefer the great coalition, but the SPD really doesn't want to, because they got harmed by this arrangement in the last few years and they will be strengthened in the opposition. The Green and the FDP have many diametrically opposed views, but they nevertheless seem reasonably willing to govern together. I tried to find information indicating that the great coalition will happen, but did not find anything new. The probability for "none of the above" seems to be split at about 7:3 for great coalition and new elections, respectively. New elections have only happened three times in Germany and none of these times because a coalition could not be formed http://www.rp-online.de/politik/deutschland/vorgezogene-neuwahlen-fragen-und-antworten-bid-1.2236397. On the other hand, afaik a great coalition has never been rejected before when there was no possibility for a clear centre-right or centre-left government, as is the case now with the FDP being centre-right and the Green centre-left.
Jamaika (Green FDP Union) is the only option that hasn't officially been ruled out by party spokespeople, but the parties diverge on many important issues.

The Left Party does not take part in the exploratory talks. So there are only option 3 and 5 left. The third week of exploratory talks ended today. According to different sources that participated in the talks, there is a growing amount of consensus. However, the issues that bear the highest risk that the government will not be formed (migration, climate, energy) are not yet being settled. Next Friday (17th), the parties will decide whether they start formal coalition talks. If they decide to start these talks, probability of option 3 will rise to 100 before the end of the year. If they do not decide to start coalition talks, probability of option 5 will be 95 by the evening of Friday 17th.

I don't see an other option as likely, but the FDP might have a long term incentive to make the CDU/CSU look weak. 
CDU/CSU = 32.9%
SDP= 20.5%
Die linke =9.2%
Grün =8.9%
FDP=10.7%
AFD =12.6%

The Jamaica coalition is the most likely choice as the Left is simply too different compared with the CDU/CSU. I also think there is a fair chance that coalition talks fall apart because the FDP, Greens, and CDU/CSU have very different plans and philosophies.
I think it very unlikely that the Left will be involved because there are too many differences with the CDU/CSU, but in German politics many things are impossibly though unlikely.
there are only 4 candidates: cdu/csu, spd, fdp, green party. never ever had the left party as a candidate for this coalition.
ha ha, is this really a serious question?
No chance at all of the Left and CDU/CSU or the FDP being in the same coalition. It's most likely Jamaica, and if not, another election or even a grand coalition despite the SPD ruling it out.
